label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, March 7, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, lamenting the arrival of inflation of food prices to the Hawaii, describing his lack of stamina in social situations anymore, and recounting events of their attempts at surfing. Sidney continues in his letter to describe the beauty of summer in Hawaii and what it will be like when they are reunited after the war.

Sidney continues in his letter to describe the beauty of summer in Hawaii and what it will be like when they are reunited after the war.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
March 7, 1943
Gertie Darling,
I have my little machine at home as I have new a
big machine in the office just like theprofessionaluse. As
a result I am knocking this lettter out with practiced fingers
at a sp[e]ed that leaves the keys red hot and littleheat waves that
shirnner in the lampflight. After reading the last few sentences
it looks as if more than the heat waves are shimmering. Morris
has gone off to xxxxxxx the movies and I am in the apartment with
a boy we brougut home form the offce called Johnny Lee. He was
at college with us, but I don't remember him. Anyway he came out
tonjgut and we took him swinming and then cooked dinner here.
We a solutley refuse to go out anymore. Inflation has struck the
island with a bang andthe dinner we use to pay ninty cents
for is now one sixty and much less is served[ Two nights ago
we ate at the outrigger and I had a dab of vegetables, not a teas
poonful, one tiny potatoe [A]nd not enough fish to bait a hook
with. One dollar and seven[t]y cents. Tonight we cooked a wonderful
can of chicken, three packages of biros eye green peas and some
sweet potatoes and I am so full andsleepy that I have to do this
letter by the touch system as otheriwse I could not write. My
big fat stomach is hanging over the key board, blotting it out
like a fat cloud. Our guest is in the living room playing the
radio. We have become quite matter of fact about them and
the Sidney as a host you use to knowdoes note[x]ist anymore.
I nm as bad as morris use to be at Medway an simply get up
and leave the room -and lying down on my bed read or go to sleep.
I know you will be ashame[d] of me and will wolrk like fury to
get me back into shape to face society when we xxxx are together
again.
I went swimming today and went out to where Morris was
riding in on big waves. He would fall off and I would roar with
laughter until some big wave would knock me down to the bottom
and fill my lungs with water. Then I would surface red eyed and
puffing and struggle about a little until I could once more gain
sufficent strenght to holler derise_ely at him as he teetered
in mid[air]. The hawaiians are so marvellous. They are like 
panthers on their boards. Half crouched with their feet dire tly
under them they move back and forth like cats judgin[g] the wave
[End Page 1]
so that they neverlose it but always keep just a little below
the crest. Duke Kahanamoko was out in a little canoe and was
a marvellous sight. He isfifty four and has the mucxles of a man
of twenty. Really marvellous looking person, with his dark skin
broad shoulders and black black hair, shooting ahead of the white
foam. Of course ashore he does not shine with the same bright
light, but that is neither here nor there.
The days are so much longer now that I know summer is
here. There is no other may to recognize its appearnace. There
is no change in temperature, the tress do not became green
flowers do not come out, but the sun shines in a cloudless sky now
and every evening at five a great shaft of color, purple vi[o]llet, 
blue and gold climbs out of the va[l]lexys and stretches in a great
arc towards diamond head. A rainbow so gorgxious , so colorful,
that it seems unreal. Th n the pigeons begin to swoop towards
the ponds and [the] hot air lies motio[n]less like a blanket over the palms
and habicus hedges that guard the sides of Kalkua avenue. The
place shakesitself witht he first breeze over the mountains and
the fronds in the plams beggn to rustle with that marvellous soun d
that lives thorughout the night,a hidden undertone to the soft
whisper of the tradex winds. The stars coast across the sky so
quikly here. I was never concious of their movements before
but here theyr ace across , constellations sweeping up
from the sea and arching across the deep blue of the heavens trailing
a soft silvery light. This evening the clearness of the air made
them especially distinct. They seemed an emanation of the sunsext
Iwish you were here with me dear so that I could put
my arm about your wai.__t and walk slowly down the alawaj watching
the stars dive into the can[a]l and lie floating on its surface,
bobbing up and down with the little waves. I f you could feel the
soft wind in your face and hear the plms rustling you would forget
how tired you were and a the dreadful life of being apart
would be athing of the past, bit it will some day sweetheart, believe
[me,] I know. How I know I cant tell you but I am absolutley certain we
will once more be togerter again and I will be able to hold you in
my arms. Then vhen I tell you that I love and adore you you will
have to believe it for I will be there to prove it, while with a 
letter there is nothing but a memory and black lines on white
paper to express what only eyes and lips can really tell. You will
see darling , some day I will be with you again to tell you that
you are everything to me. Then I will kiss you [so] hard that you will
beg for mercy, and I will hug youwith such a great hug that you
wont have any strength to anything so I will pick you up and carry
you up to our room and love you for ever and ever.
.
Goodbye darling, please let me know how your trip is
comming along and when you expect to leave. I am so thrilled
by your ability and the offer of this wonderful job for you.
You are marvellous Gertie and I know will make a great succes of it.
with all my love. 
Sidney
[End Page 2]
